segments.text: 1988 at Bryan High concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the A&M Oral History Collection.
Is that okay with you, Mr. Price?
Yes.
Okay.
Could you please tell us when and where you were born?
I was born in Abilene, Texas in 1939.
Okay.
Where did you go to high school and college?
I went to high school at a little place called Hawley.
And my college is at Texas A&M University.
I have two degrees from there.
Okay, what are those degrees in?
I have a Bachelor of Science in Industrial Education, a Master of Science in Industrial Education, and currently working on a PhD in Educational Administration.
Okay, when and where and why exactly did you join the military?
I joined the military in 1957, about three months after I graduated from high school.
crime cause.
At the time, it was sort of impossible to go to college.
That was an alternative open to me.
I took it and just stayed in.
Made a career of it.
Had your father or any of your brothers been in the military?
To my knowledge, I was the first.
Okay.
Could you please give us a brief sketch of your military career before Vietnam?
Before Vietnam, I had spent approximately
15 years in the military, various places around the world, mostly in overseas areas in the Far East.
Five years in Central and South America.
The main drill is pretty much in the Far East.
I got into Europe for about six months on a TDY mission one time, but it never really went that way.
What was the TDY mission?
We went over on a major operation and we were there for approximately six months.
We took a division over with maneuvers and stayed about six months and came back.
Okay.
Upon going to Vietnam, how much did you know and how much had the military taught you about Vietnam, say, their culture and Buddhism and geography, et cetera?
Prior to going over, I went to Fort Bragg, North Carolina for a period of 60 days.
at which time we were given refresher courses on weapons that were primarily World War II and Korean War vintage that we hadn't been using to bring us back into contact with them.
Some older communications equipment we had.
During that period of time, we had four hours of Vietnamese language training every day.
some general background classes on the political aspects of Vietnam at the time, and as much of an update on the military situation as possible.

And to some extent, we had some cultural indoctrination in that our language teachers were all Vietnamese, and had just recently come from Vietnam, so we were acquiring something of a cultural aspect also.
So you were able to communicate pretty well?
I never really found out.

I got a few opportunities to speak, but mostly my counterparts were Arvin officers, and they seemed to have one goal in mind at the time, to learn to speak English well enough that they could go to an offshore school, which meant come to the States and attend school here.
If they couldn't speak English,
proficiently, they would never get the opportunity to attend one of those schools.
When I dealt with them, I had to speak in English, but they would talk Vietnamese with me.
I never dealt too awfully much with the enlisted.
I didn't really have a counterpart on the enlisted side.
For some reason, in their military, the enlisted, even the NCOs, weren't given that much latitude or authority.
So if I wanted something done, I dealt with an officer, and that made
some problems, and because of this cultural thing they had, sort of a case system within the Army.
They didn't really want to deal with me, but they had to.
I spoke Vietnamese to the villagers when they would talk to me, but that was a matter of if there were no Arvin around, they would talk to me.
If the Arvin were there, they would not talk to me.
Probably didn't get to practice my language very much then.
Did you feel any resentment as
How the officers treated you like that?
No.
I accepted it as their system.
I thought it was rather foolish not to take advantage of the NCOs like any other army does.
Realistically, the officers can't run the army.
There's an old saying in our army, the NCO is the backbone of the army.
You take the NCO away, you don't really have an army.
The officers can't do it.
They have too many other things.
It was rather apparent in the army that
the officers trying to do everything themselves, not letting the NCOs have the responsibility they should, but things got bogged down considerably.
Um, did you, were you in your unit, did you have a clear overall picture of what exactly what America was trying to accomplish there, or were you just sort of part of the big picture?
Well, within our province,
I had a pretty firm view of where we were headed since I worked at both the province level and the district level.
I started at the district level, but we were pretty well indoctrinated in country as to what our goals were at the district level.
And about halfway through my first tour, I moved up to the province level working with the operations and intelligence and with the civilian side of the house also.
At that point, we were pretty well indoctrinated about what the whole concept was for the province and the country.
So I had a realistic view of where we were supposed to be going with it.

And that was pacification and reinserting the people back into lands that they had given up to the BC previously, which was primarily what we were trying to do, just regain the land and get rid of the BC.
or reduce the VC to a level that the locals could manage without a great deal of military.
Could you give us just an example of what your unit would typically do in terms of pacification?
Our program of pacification, when I first arrived, was one of simply trying to regain land.
At that point, this was shortly after Tet, 1968,
My province, probably one of the worst in the whole of Vietnam, the birthplace of the VC movement.
So they were pretty well entrenched.
After Tet in 1968, they were very weakened because of the loss of manpower.
And we were expanding back out into areas that the government forces had withdrawn out of.
So we were, at that point in time, simply in the process of establishing
fortified outposts out into an area and sort of a circular effect.
We'd move them further out to try and gain back control of that area.
Sort of the inkblot.
Yeah, so kind of like an inkblot, like a ripple.
You throw stone in the water, you get ripples.
That's what we were doing.
We were expanding out from the district capital, trying to get control of the property back that we had given up at some previous time.
And we were
pretty effective during that period.
We lost a little bit, but we eventually worked it back.
And then I went back a year later for a second tour.
I went back to the same place, and I could see what we had done in two years' time.
Had it improved?
Oh, considerably.
We were considered one of our district's
The one that the VC movement was born in, we had taken it back almost 100%.
It was turned into what they would call a showcase of South Vietnam.
We had officials from all over the country coming to see what we had done and how we had done it.
So we were successful within our province and the one across the river, Gokong Province, which was also very heavily infested.
They were successful enough with their program also that between the two,
provinces, we had got it fairly well pacified.
We didn't have a great deal of VC activity when I left there on my second tour.
Was there, you say not a great deal, was there any VC activity at night that you didn't see during the daytime?
Oh, there were sporadic raids and occasional mortaring, but we didn't really experience a great deal of heavy encounters.
Occasionally, there'd be a transiting
hardcore unit that somebody might stumble across and have contact with.
We didn't really have any major hardcore units after 1968.
They were pretty much eliminated.
In fact, all the hardcore units had been moved up to higher levels.
The battalions had been pulled out and sent up to attack Corps headquarters in Saigon, places like that.
The companies had been pulled up to higher levels.
Practically all of our hardcore
regular units had been eliminated because they had been taken out and used and attacked somewhere else.
All we had left was a few stragglers and they were trying to rebuild.
They weren't very successful after Tet.
What was your opinion of, or is your opinion of, the effectiveness of pacification overall?
Because it was a lot of programs.
That's kind of a hard one.
It depends on where you were as to what pacification meant.
Wasn't Project Phoenix also considered pacification?
Was it not pacification?
I guess it would be considered part of the pacification program in that they were trying to eliminate the VC Cadry, the infrastructure out in the field.
To that extent, it probably was part of the pacification, but we didn't really consider it part of our pacification program.
We had no control over it.
It was primarily controlled by people in Saigon.
We had people in our province who were working in the program, but we had no say over what they did or didn't do.
So we didn't really consider them part of our program.
In the big picture, yes, they were trying to eliminate the infrastructure, so I suppose that's pacification to that way of thinking.
It varied from province to province.
The people in the northern provinces were working at it slightly different than we were.
They relied much, much more heavily on the military to pass by regular army units because up there they were dealing with a different type situation.
The number of hardcore units and North Vietnamese units made it almost impossible for the locals to deal with it at the level we were dealing with.
And our people were primarily
the regional force, popular force, platoons and companies.
They're not very well trained and not very well armed, just locals trying to protect their home, which wouldn't work in, say, I Corps or II Corps up north.
We'd be constantly looking at NVA battalions and larger.
Did you and your unit ever experience any actual combat with North Vietnam troops or the Viet Cong?
So far as we know,
There were never any NVA in our area.
We don't know of any.
There were rumors at one or two times that there were some Chinese advisors.
And at one point someone even started a rumor about a Russian advisory possibly, but that didn't get off the ground too much.
But the Chinese advisory rumor floated a little bit.
We never found anything to substantiate it.
We could never get any sightings.
As far as we know, it was purely .
The only thing we were dealing with was VC and local VC at that, just I guess on the level of the militia VC and occasional hardcore unit that would come through.
But no NVA to our knowledge.
One problem that seems to be picked up a lot in literature and movies now is drugs in Vietnam and such.
Did you ever experience any trouble with drugs?
We had, to my knowledge, in the two years there, only one incident with drugs.
And these people were from an aviation battalion who had been put with us.
And the only thing we had were two pilots and a couple of crew chiefs to keep their light observation aircraft flying out of our airfield.
They were found with marijuana.
So it wasn't that bad of a problem for them.
They were just using marijuana, nothing in the way of hard drugs or anything.
To my knowledge, they were the only ones.
They weren't in the same category as the rest of us.
The rest of us were advisors who belonged to MACV.
Those people were out of a regular American aviation unit and assigned to us for assistance.
So the type of personnel is slightly different.
If you understand, the American units probably had a lower caliber of people than the advisors did, because all the advisors were officers, high-ranking non-commissioned officers.
We had a few of the lower enlisted, but they were few and far between.
So you didn't really come into contact with many enlisted men?
On a large scale?
Not below the rank of E-5, no.
The E-4 and the privates, PFCs, we didn't really, there was no place for them.
We had no place in our table of organization for those people to be there.
Everything we had called for an NCO or an officer, so they were at least E-5 and up.
Occasionally we would get an E-4 in as a radio operator, but that was about the extent of it.
Okay, another popular saying among the, I don't know, among the officers, but about some officers, that they just were concerned about getting their ticket punched.
Did your unit experience any trouble with, you know, career-hungry officers or people that just wanted to advance themselves?
Was that counterproductive at all?
To a point, perhaps.
But you have to understand that that ticket punching thing didn't apply to
People in the advisory, they didn't have the same opportunity for command that people in the regular units.
An officer would come to Vietnam if he went to a normal unit.
He was expected to go up on the front and command a platoon, or a company, or a battalion, or whatever, depending on what was ranked, to get his command time.
There really was no equivalency of a command in the advisory effort.
For instance, an advisory team at district was made up of a major, a captain,
One sergeant first class, a staff sergeant for a medic, an E-5 for a radio operator.
That's not much of a command.
You don't command anybody.
So what was happening in Arvin is, or in the advisory effort, is that they would be given credit for command time for one year to it.
So they would get credit for command time.
So there wasn't any of this trying to find a job where you could lead troops in combat.
If you were there as an advisor, after one year you were given the prerequisite command time that every officer wanted to have on his record when he left there.
When they came into the advisory effort, they were assigned a job.
They stayed with that job for the whole year.
There was no shifting around, so we didn't have that much of a problem in terms of rapid turnover of leaders and inconsistency and incontinuity of command.
You were there for a year.
You did your year at that job, and you were home.
That short period caused
continuity to break off, but still, it wasn't that difficult to come in and pick up an advisory job if you'd been given any training at all before you got there.
The establishing of relationships was probably the biggest thing you had to go through, and that probably took about 90 days before you really established any rapport with your counterpart.
productivity didn't fall off much or anything, because very seldom you'd ever lose the entire team at one time.
It'd be an individual at times, so the incoming person didn't really fall into a hole, so to speak.
There were people there who were already in place and functioning, so they could support the effort until he got himself, you know, got his feet wet and ready to go.
So we didn't face the same problems that a regular unit would face with that type of changeover.
Do you feel that overall the war could have been better fought had there not been a one-year tour of duty?
Had there been, you know, an unlimited tour, say, or something like in World War II?
I'm sure it probably could have, just from the experience factor alone.
By the time you got a good understanding of how the war was supposed to be fought, it was time to go home.
Maybe your replacement came in who had been there, and he was coming back for seconds, and he knew what to do.
If he was a first-timer, then he had to go through the learning process.
And there's not really much you can tell an individual about how you're going to work in combat.
I mean, you have the basic idea to have the correct training, the tactics, the theory, and everything.
But the actual situation is oftentimes far removed from what the training was.
You had at least a background to work with, and you had to adapt.
to what the situation was, and that created the problem with the short tour.
So I would say, yes, probably could have been done better if everybody had stayed there, as in World War II, duration plus five.
Then we would have had people there who were constantly doing the job that they were trying to do, if they learned what they were supposed to do.
I kind of look at the French.
They kept their people there almost constantly.
There was no rotation in and out for those people, but from the looks of what happened to them and many of the history lessons that I've looked up, it's how the French fought.
They didn't learn much.
They were fighting, trying to fight a conventional
similar to what they fought in World War II that wasn't working for them.
And they got away from that and went into the enclave theory, the fortified outposts and what have you.
That didn't work either because it turned the whole countryside over to the Viet Minh at the time.
So if they learned something and conducted the war in a fashion that you could counter what the enemy did, then yes, it would have been productive to keep everybody there.
Because then you would have people who knew what to do, constantly.
Do you feel that the U.S. should have learned or could have learned a lesson from the French and the Viet Minh and apply that to the Viet Cong in terms of conventional warfare?
We couldn't have learned anything from the French.
We were using some of the French tactics.
And it turns out it didn't work for them.
It didn't work for us either.
We were doing some of the very same things that the French did.
In fact, almost everything the French did, we were doing, except the very large, large outposts like Dien Bien Phu and a few places like that.
We had large fire bases and everything, but we never settled down in one place that long, so we differed from the French in that respect.
But we were doing a lot of the things the French did in every aspect of it.
It turned out it didn't work for us either because we couldn't control the land.
There's an old saying in combat, or if you don't control the other guy's property, then you can't win.
So we never were sure that we controlled anything other than what we were physically standing on top of at the time.
You go into an area, you supposedly clear that area, and then we leave.
Five hours after we leave, the VC are back.
That's one of their base areas, and they go right back into it.
They sort of go with the flow, so to speak.
They pull away if we're too strong.
If we're not strong enough, they might give it a shot, see if they can do something to us, but very seldom did they ever try to hit us face on unless they had at least a 3-1 superiority on us.
Other than that, it was just a little hit and run, disappear into the brush.
Did your unit ever leave the land it had reoccupied with the South Vietnamese, and if so, did the VC move back in?
In my tours and in between the tours, the land that we had moved back in and occupied or put out on some was still under our control when I left at the end of the third year.
We were still there, pretty well entrenched, and the people were coming back to the land
Some had never left, of course, but a few that did were moving back out.
We were expanding out beyond those ranges anyway.
So as far as I can see, we never lost any ground after 68-12.
Do you feel that, though, if your unit had pulled out in the foreseeable future, would the Viet Cong have come back?
Well, if we're speaking of the advisors,
I don't think so, because we weren't doing any fighting.
Five guys out there in the middle of nowhere can't.
Realistically, we weren't a combat force.
We were there just to tell other people.
But they were reaching a point where they could do fairly well on their own.
A good example, the advisory effort was starting to wind down before I left here.
And they were pulling people out of the Arvin units.
So at the time I left, all of the advisors
at the company level and the battalion levels had been removed.
And the only people left still advising were at regiments and division headquarters level.
And that was only two or three people.
And as best we could tell, those units that were working in and around our areas were doing a better job than they had when the advisors were there.
Because they had to do the job then.
With the advisors on hand, a lot of the things that the Arvins should have been doing, the advisors were doing.
In a sense, the people who worked with the Arvin were their own worst enemies.
They weren't letting the Arvin do the job when it should have been done.
The old American, go get them, we've got to do it now, hurry up, sort of got in the way.
The Vietnamese didn't work in that fashion.
They were playing at it very slowly.
If it took five days to do something, then that's the way they went at it.
But the Americans didn't want to work that slow.
You start an operation, you want to get it bang, bang, bang, get it done.

And they would short circuit the Vietnamese just to get things moving faster, and it took away, to me, some of the initiative that the Vietnamese should have had and weren't showing because they knew the Americans were going to do it for them.
And when those people left, those divisions appeared to be working better
than they were when they had the Americans down to company levels.
Do you feel that careerism and officer advancement was a problem in Arvin, and did that, and corruption possibly, did that affect the way they fought?
I would think probably it had to.
Several instances come to mind.
One, we had some
Candidates for officers and candidates for warrant officer, we were trying to get promoted locally, and we couldn't do it.
They would make them acting officers, but the best we could find out is they didn't belong to the right family or they didn't have the proper connections to be commissioned.
So there was, I guess, what you would have to call a case system.
Either you belonged to the right family or you had the right connection to become an officer.
And it was very unlikely that anyone else would ever do it.
And then as far as corruption around, there was some.
We know for a fact that some of the jobs were being paid for.
It was pretty much a standing joke.
If you wanted to be a province chief, you'd come up with $25,000 to $50,000, depending on which province you wanted to go.
You could get the job.
district chiefs were a little bit less, but there were places that officers could go and make pretty good money at it, because they were rampant corruption going on.
We knew that, but there's not much we could do about it.
We had to live with it.
It depended on how well the guy did his job in relation to making all the money for himself.
An example, one of the first district chiefs I ran into when I got there was a major
Our district was very well controlled.

He was doing an excellent job, but he kind of got caught up short somewhere from what we heard when he got relieved and that he wasn't paying enough kickback to the people upstairs and they fired him.
And his replacement, while he might have been paying the kickback and everything, he wasn't doing the job that the Major did and we were losing the ground with him until we got him replaced.
He was pretty much satisfied with the status quo.
We don't do anything.
D.C. don't do anything.
We just sit here and watch.
It took a while to get rid of him, but eventually we could.
With enough pressure from the top side, we forced him to be removed.
I'm sure there was corruption everywhere.
From what we can see in here, it's not something we set out to prove, but you could always make a case for it, I guess, if you wanted to.
Did you and your colleagues there feel really frustrated, like you were just spinning your wheels with a bunch of corrupt officers?
Did y'all waste any time at all?
Maybe, perhaps it was our province, but we had a pretty good group of people there as far as I could see.
Our province chief was a lieutenant colonel, and he was very good at his job.
and running the civilian side of the government and also the military side operations.
One of the better people that I knew out there.
I don't think that overall we had too much of a problem with them.
We were getting what we wanted done with them.
Sometimes it was frustrating that we didn't seem to be moving fast enough.
I guess that's the Americans.
get up and go get them right now, and let's not wait any time.
So that was the only thing that was really frustrating.
We didn't seem to be moving at a fast enough rate for where we wanted to go, but that's the difference in cultures.
They just didn't work at the same speed we wanted to.
This probably wasn't common or might have even been nonexistent among you and other MACD officers, but were you aware of any incidents at all of bragging or men killing their own officers?
among the Americans, sir?
Not in our, in the advisory.
I doubt seriously that any of that would have occurred.
Some misleading movies out, Platoon, I think, had an incident where several sergeants were talking about, you know, fragging an officer.
One other TV show, Vietnam Story,
I had an incident on one of theirs where an entire group of NCOs and privates were going to frag the company commander, but those were in the line units.
And the advisory had a much closer knit group, five or six people.
If you work in a province, you only have 30 or 40 people there.
And everybody's fairly high-ranking NCOs and officers, so we didn't have that kind of a problem.
I don't know of any incident of any advisory personnel being fragged.
What did you think of the motivation and the inspiration of the Arvin troops compared to the North Vietnamese troops?
Rather poor.

have to attribute their lack of motivation to their leadership and the leadership being what it was somewhat poor the way they went about it as a comparison at the district i had one company and one platoon who were all xbc they had come over on the chew white program which when they surrendered they were repatriated given some indoctrination and training and allowed to go back to where they came from most of them joined the rf companies the pf companies so we had one company was all
XBC and one platoon that was all XBC.
In comparison to the other companies they had, they were much more aggressive and a whole lot more willing to get out and do the job.
In terms of going out with someone, after I kind of got over the idea that they were XBC, I found it a whole lot easier to get things done and felt a lot safer going out with those people.
It was like they were telling them to do what they wanted to do,

and when the shooting started they wanted to get involved in it whereas the other companies you might just look around find yourself standing there by yourself because they've gone the other direction so i would think they were much much better motivated for whatever reason they were motivated or how they got them motivated i don't know but they seem to be more motivated than they are overall do you think it's fair to say you could attribute that to the fact that that the north had ho chi minh to rally around whereas the south the government was more or less just

were no stable leaders for the people well if you're talking about nba probably talking about vc uh the average vc is where we were uh didn't know much about ho chi minh and could care less what he wanted or didn't want the vc in the southern part of the country were being motivated locally by i guess nationalism if you want to look at it that way we could never really get any

your idea some of that drafted but whatever means they used to get them indoctrinated to get a more motivated it was working people they just go on the village okay you know part of the BC but they got more out of them than the garbage to get out of them or whatever means they were using they didn't usually want to talk to you too much about
how they got into it.
The biggest thing I could see was that many of them were disappointed or disillusioned with what the B.C.
had offered and was reasonably quick.
It wasn't turning out to be exactly the picture that the B.C.
probably had sold them when they went with them.
They were just getting a little frustrated out there that nothing was happening like they were supposed to.
They couldn't see any progress being made.
If the B.C.
were any better than the other, they were much more in danger of being with the B.C., so they eventually just give it up and quit.
Do you think there was any cooperation between the North Vietnamese and the Viet Cong, or were they two separate entities?
I don't really know.
From reports, we do know that toward the latter end of the war, the NVA were, in some cases, actually running the VC units.
They went in first as advisors with them.
We do know that some of the BC units in the northern areas were being led by North Vietnamese officers toward the latter part of the war.
There was some distrust in the southern part, as best we can find out.
They didn't really trust the few NVA that got down into that area.
They were mostly over toward the Cambodian border, but from reports and intel we could get from over there,
The few NVA that were down there weren't really accepted and nobody really trusted them as far as they could find out.
There was always that feeling they were trying to take over.
That's one theory that kept cropping up.
The NVA were trying to take over.
The few high-ranking officers and officials from the VC that did defect

pretty much were putting that idea forth, that they had a feeling that if they did win, that the NBA was going to be in trouble and not the D.C. That was kind of a brink point for some of them, particularly the high-ranking people that defected.
On how effective a strategy do you think bombing was in Vietnam?
Should there have been more, say, in the North or in Laos and Cambodia?
Bombing in South Vietnam, I don't know.
I have to go on speculation and stories.
We had no bombing in our area.
We had one or two B-52 strikes that I can remember, and as far as where they went, I could see no value for them anyway.
They were in suspected BC areas and out in the mangrove swamps.
as the best as we could determine later after looking at the strike assessment photos.
We tore up a lot of mango trees and made some bigger pools out there, but fortunately, no, we didn't hurt anybody.
I have a feeling that dropping that stuff in the jungle was about the same effect.
You knocked down a lot of trees and made a few clearings here and there, but effectively you were hoping you were going to hit something with all that bombing.
Occasionally they would get lucky, but I don't know.
in the South that the bombing was all that effective.
Maybe in the North, if some of the targets had been changed, it might have changed the complexion of the war, but that's pure speculation.
Do you think that the United States could have won the war?
And if so, maybe, you know, with more pacification, and what kind of programs would you have had a choice?
If I would have had a choice,
We would have left there.
I think Kennedy at one point was talking about pulling all the advisers out before his assassination.
I think somewhere in the administration at that time, there was already the feeling that we couldn't win the thing over there.
And the rumors were floating up and down to the military at the time.
I was still here in the States.
There were things being put out inside the Army probably in the military that civilians were never made aware of.
But there was a pretty definite feel that Kennedy wanted to get us out of there.
He couldn't see any way to win the thing, except just get much, much more involved.
And even then, he couldn't really.
Some of his people were telling him, no matter what we put in there, we couldn't win the war.
Johnson came along, it changed for whatever reason.
Whether it was the macho image we can't afford to back down or whatever, I'm not sure.

I don't know that we could have done anything differently that would have made any difference in the outcome unless we were willing to make a total commitment to a war and put whatever manpower and machine power it required to get in there and physically take every inch of ground away from them right up to the Chinese border.
then you might have effectively won the war, but you would have had to control North Vietnam also.
Do you think that the Viet Cong were just too deeply rooted into South Vietnam by the time the U.S. entered, or was that part of the problem?
By the time we got into it, they were well entrenched.
A lot of those people were Viet Minh that had stayed in the South after the separation of the French left.
A lot of them were Viet Minh who had infiltrated south after that period of time and started the V.C.
movement down south.
The V.C.
movement wasn't what we were fighting initially or what the Arvin was fighting initially.
They were fighting Viet Minh just like the French were.
Eventually it changed over to V.C.
with the local southern organization.
But they were pretty well entrenched already.
had been built up during World War II, had been built up during the fighting of the French, and essentially the cadre and everybody were in place.
It was just a matter of recruitment to build up the forces.
I think that they lost an opportunity to settle, I think, politically in French land, realistically, considering everything

Dr. Anderson's talk about it and everything I've read or heard since then, it really, we lost it when we refused to talk to Ho Chi Minh, and we lost it again when the French left, when they should have just turned it back over to the Vietnamese and let them settle it themselves.
That's a personal view.
I don't really see that we could have done anything realistically that would have changed it, maybe prolonged it somewhat, but I don't think it would have changed.
A lot of people seem to think that after Tet, the Viet Cong and the North Vietnamese were so weak and that we could have won.
Do you feel that without the media and protesters bringing such a negative image on the war, do you feel we could have won?
I think, and this is personal opinion, that if we ever were going to win the war, it would have had to have been after Tet.
We would have had to have committed
110% and gone in and done the job.
Because we did a very thorough job on destroying most of all the hardcore VC units in the South.
And a great deal of damage inflicted on whatever NVA units had participated.
So I think if we ever had a chance to win, it was immediately after 10.
We didn't follow up on it.
And yes, the news media
was probably a direct cause of why we didn't.
They looked upon it as a defeat.
And all the military experts tell you, we won.
We won.
And we had them on the ropes and ready for the count if we'd just gone in and done something else.
But we backed off because of this publicity and outcry at home.
What's your opinion of draft dodgers and anti-war protesters, like Jane Fonda, for example?
Well, the draft dodgers that left the country, I didn't agree with them.
But on the other hand, I couldn't say they were wrong.
If you believe in something strongly enough, then obviously you have a right to do it.
like to tell people occasionally.
I stood in front of the flag for 22 years to give a guy a right to do that.
So who am I to criticize him if he goes if I'm defending his right to do it?
And I can't criticize him if he goes.
I had more respect for those people than I did for some of the anti-war protesters, particularly the ones that tried to

influence the gis here in the states those who are out there trying to work on the public is one thing those who aim directly at the military and try to influence the desertion rate the awol rate those they weren't really doing anything to me it was worthwhile the others
I guess if you look at the broad view, they were influencing the political arena.
If you want something done, you have to influence politics.
Those people who were trying to convert people and get them to desert were...
I don't feel they had a right to be doing that.
If anybody had anything against anybody within that particular group, the rest of them...
They were doing their thing, I was doing mine.
As long as we didn't really get in conflict with each other, I couldn't see anything wrong with it.
They were entitled to do it.
They were right to do it.
How realistic do you think movies like a few popular ones were, Platoon, The Deer Hunter, Apocalypse Now, how realistic were those in portraying like in Vietnam?
Deer Hunter is a farce.
It had nothing to do with Vietnam.
If they were trying to put across a theme, I'm not sure what theme they were trying to put across.
But in terms of being realistic about the war, total bummer.
Full metal jacket.
That's based on Marines.
I've never had much of a concept of Marines doing anything right.
Still, I couldn't see that even Marines would be doing things as stupid as some things were going on in that movie.
The only one I've seen that has any realistic idea to me of what the war is going is Platoon.
It got down pretty much at that level on the front line with the guys.

There's some things that showed or portrayed in the movie that probably wouldn't have been happening in the actual situation, but it's about as close to realistic as I can see from the movies I've seen.
It's about the most realistic down at the front line level.
Some things in it I was sort of blown out of proportion, but it made the movie better.
I gave the story a little bit more zip or whatever you want to look at it, but
On the whole, it probably is the most realistic portrayal of what the frontline soldiers were involved in.
The rest of them was just sort of, I don't know, a bump to me.
They didn't portray the war.

They put across other messages, but it wasn't, if that was their attempt to put some other message across, they did that very well, but didn't, as far as showing what the war was, not a very good portrayal.
What do you think about the stereotype that persists in a lot of these movies about the unstable, mentally unstable, who can't adjust to society?
Is that realistic at all?
Well, we're dealing with a portrayal of a one-time, one-tour person.
And I have friends who were there a lot longer than I was.
I spent two tours there.
I had friends who were there as much as eight years.
I think if anybody was in a position to become paranoid, we were.
You're 60, 70 miles away from nobody, and the only thing you've got to rely on is the guy next to you and some doubtful Vietnamese to keep you alive.
If anybody should have come out of there paranoid, it probably should have been us.
Personally, I think that most of these cases are real...
off the deep end type when you get back here.
There was something on the unstable side before they went anywhere.
Vietnam just was the trigger.
Had they stayed at home, it would have happened anyway at some later date because of something else.
Most of the people I know who were there two or three times weren't affected like that.
So I don't see how other people decided.
Being there at one time would drive somebody over the deep end unless he wasn't already somewhere.
pretty close to that point anyway.
Any other type of pressure or situation later on probably would have gotten the same results.

It's just that it was much more compact and put on him in a very short space of time in Vietnam where it would have just taken a longer time to build up out here, but I think it would have happened anyway.
So to me it's unfair to say that
